Graphical abstract The effect of noble metal (NM) promoter (Pt, Re, or Ru) deposition order was investigated for commercially-representative Co Fischer–Tropsch catalysts (nominally 25wt% Co on a La stabilized alumina support). The effects of deposition sequence (co-deposition vs. sequential deposition) were studied in terms of NM retention and distribution, Co crystallite size, Co reducibility, and catalyst activity and selectivity. Ru retention was <48% for both sequences with the most severe losses for co-deposition (85% loss). Sequentially deposited Co/Ru showed poor Ru distribution, unlike co-deposited Co/Ru. Excellent retention and uniform distribution were observed for both Pt and Re promoted catalysts. Cobalt crystallite sizes were smaller for all three co-deposited catalysts (∼4.2nm for all NMs) when compared to any of the sequentially deposited catalysts. Although sequentially deposited catalysts required higher reduction temperatures (TPR), they had greater extents of reduction (EORs) relative to co-deposited catalysts. CO depletion rates and turnover frequencies (TOFs) for co-deposited Co/Pt and Co/Re were 2–3 times higher than their sequentially deposited counterparts. Methane selectivities were lower for the same two co-deposited catalysts. It is noteworthy that the smaller Co crystallites, produced by co-deposition, resulted in more active catalysts than those with larger crystallites resulting from sequential deposition. The co-deposited Co/Pt catalyst was found to be statistically more active than the unpromoted Co catalyst, while the corresponding sequentially deposited catalyst was less active. Overall, co-deposited Co/Pt and Co/Re catalysts showed superior catalytic performance by all standards of judgment when compared to their sequentially deposited counterparts. Keywords Cobalt Cobalt catalysis Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Catalytic promoters Deposition order Crystallite size Pt Re Ru 1 Introduction Continual research on supported cobalt Fischer–Tropsch (FT) catalysts has led to the formulation of different preparation techniques to produce catalysts with varied FT synthesis performance. Noble metals (NMs) have been widely used as promoters to improve the structure, dispersion, reducibility, selectivity and activity of these catalysts. Although the order in which the Co and NMs are deposited onto the support has been shown to sometimes make a difference, there is no clear answer as to which order is optimal. The two most prevalent deposition sequences described in literature are designated as follows: (1) Sequential deposition (seq-dep): the cobalt-containing precursor is deposited in one or more steps which are separate from the step in which the NM is deposited. (2) Co-deposition (co-dep): the cobalt precursor (containing at least part of the total Co loading) is deposited at the same time or in the same step as the NM. Specific to this study, seq-dep refers to the deposition of the NM in one separate step after Co is deposited onto the support in three previous steps with a high temperature calcination step in between each step; co-dep refers to the deposition of the NM with Co in the third and final Co deposition step. Co Fischer–Tropsch (FT) catalysts have been prepared by co-dep [1–8] and seq-dep with [9–11] and without [5,12–16] a calcination step in between the Co and NM depositions. There is a lack of agreement in the literature in regards to which deposition procedure is preferable. Beuther has made catalysts by both co-dep and seq-dep and suggests that co-dep is more convenient, although seq-dep with calcinations in between yields similar catalyst performance [17]. Kobylinski also claims that Ru and other promoters (such as La) may be added either together with the Co for convenience or in an additional deposition step [18]. Iglesia suggests that Co reduction promotion requires calcination of the NM and Co together, but that deposition order is not signficant as long as there is not a calcination in between the depositions. This claim is based on the finding that calcination with both Co and NM present allows for the migration of NM and Co surface oxides, which produces the intimate contact required for catalytic reduction promotion [19]. Furthermore, Iglesia indicates that a re-reduction along with the calcination is required for the best results [12]. On the other hand, not all studies agree with this idea, as Vada found that both Pt and Re promote reduction of Co when the catalyst is prepared by seq-dep with calcinations in between the deposition steps [9]. In fact, a review of Vada and Koblylinksi's studies suggest that either intimate contact necessary for reduction promotion is achieved with seq-dep or it is not required. While literature reports are scarce in describing the effects of deposition order in FT catalysts, a comparative literature review suggests that deposition order does affect catalyst particle size and overall performance. For example, Co agglomeration is considered to occur during thermal treatments [20], which leads to the hypothesis that the seq-deposited catalysts would have larger Co crystallite sizes due to the additional drying and calcination steps. This effect on crystallite size distribution may also affect activity/selectivity and reducibility of the catalysts, as small particles (specifically, less than 6nm) have been found to be less active, more selective to methane, and more difficult to reduce [21]. Previous studies from our laboratory reported the effects of different NMs (Pt, Re, or Ru) added by seq-dep to promote alumina-supported Co FT catalysts [22]. These studies reported the effects of the three NMs on several catalyst properties, including metal retention, metal distribution and oxidation state/bonding, as well as Co reducibility and crystallite size, with only a brief comparison of activity/selectivity properties. The objective of the current work is to take the previous work a step further by comparing and contrasting the performance of alumina supported Co FT catalysts prepared by both the co-dep and seq-dep methods for all three NMs (Pt, Re, or Ru). The performance indicators that were studied include NM retention and distribution, Co crystallite size, Co reducibility, and catalyst activity/selectivity. It should be noted that while all of the results reported in this work for the co-dep catalysts are new and original to this publication, many of the results reported for the seq-dep catalysts are the same as reported in the previous publication [22] in order to compare the effects of co-dep to seq-dep. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation NM-promoted 25% Co/La/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a three-step (co-dep) or four-step (seq-dep) wet impregnation (see Section 2.1 in the previous work [22] for a detailed description of the carrier material and its preparation). The distinguishing steps of these two processes, co-dep and seq-dep, are depicted in Figs. 1 and 2 , respectively. The first two steps in both deposition techniques were the same—Co nitrate impregnations to 10wt% and 20wt% Co, each followed by drying in a rotary evaporator and then drying and calcining in flowing air. The third step of the co-dep process included simultaneous additions of the NM (as a chloride salt) and sufficient Co nitrate to reach a total of 25wt% Co. The seq-dep process included a third step in which Co nitrate was added to reach a total of 25wt% Co and a fourth step to deposit the NM (as the chloride salt). The targeted NM loadings in each of these processes were in the range of 0.3–0.6wt% (a NM/Co molar ratio of 0.007). 2.2 Surface area, pore volume, and pore size BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore size were measured by N2 physisorption at −196°C using a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 automated system. The samples (0.15–0.25g) were degassed overnight in N2 at atmospheric pressure (∼0.862bar) and 120°C and measurements were taken immediately after degassing. The total pore volume was calculated from the amount of vapor adsorbed at a relative pressure close to unity with the assumption that the pores were filled with the condensate in the liquid state. The pore size distribution curves were calculated from the desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) formula [23]. 2.3 Metal retention and distribution Atomic adsorption-inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurements were made to determine Co and NM weight loadings for each of the calcined catalysts. Electron microprobe scans on pellets of each catalyst were also obtained to determine the distributions of Co, NMs, and La across the pellets [22]. 2.4 Co crystallite size TEM measurements were done on several hundred Co crystallites (400+) of each catalyst with the same method described previously [22]. These images were used to determine average Co crystallite diameters (ACDs) and Co crystallite size distributions (CSDs). Surface mean ACDs were calculated from the following equation: (1) d surfaceavg = ∑ i d i 3 ∑ i d i 2 where d i is the measured diameter of each particle and d surfaceavg is the surface averaged particle diameter [24]. 2.5 Noble metal oxidation state and bonding X-ray adsorption fine structure (XAFS) experiments were performed at Argonne National Laboratory's (Argonne, IL) Advanced Photon Source (APS) to determine the oxidation state and bonding of the NMs. Calcined catalysts were crushed to a fine powder and pressed into self-supporting pellets in a stainless-steel sample holder. For reduced state experiments, the catalysts were treated in a 4% (v/v) H2/He mixture for 1h, cooled, and purged with He. 2.6 Reducibility Catalyst reducibility was determined by TPR and O2 titration measurements. The latter was used to determine the extent of reduction (EOR) of reduced catalyst samples. The EOR was calculated from the weight gain of the sample during exposure to O2 at 400°C. It is assumed that during the reduction, Co3O4 is first converted to CoO and subsequently partially converted to Co0. Thus, during oxidation of the reduced catalyst, the O2 uptake includes the moles required for conversion of fully reduced Co0 to Co3O4 (Eq. (2)) and partially reduced CoO to Co3O4 (Eq. (3)). This consideration is more comprehensive than most EOR calculations found in literature. The EOR calculations were then combined with H2 chemisorption results to obtain Co dispersion, %D (Eq. (4)) and average crystallite diameter, d c (Eq. (5)). Detailed procedures for these calculations are found in the previous work [22]. (2) 3Co0 +2O2 →Co3O4 (3) 6CoO+O2 →2Co3O4 (4) %D =1.18χ/EOR/W (5) d c =94/(%D) where χ is the H2 uptake in μmol g cat − 1 , EOR is the fraction of Co3O4 that is reduced to Co0 [22], and W is the weight% of Co in the catalyst. 2.7 Activity/selectivity The fixed bed experiments to determine activity and selectivity were carried out in two parallel stainless steel tubular flow microreactors (9.5mm OD). The catalyst bed consisted of 0.25g samples diluted in 2g of white quartz sand (Sigma-Aldrich, −50/+70Mesh) used to improve the isothermality of the reactor. Prior to catalytic experiments, the samples were reduced in-situ using the reduction profile described in Section 2.1 of [22] . Catalytic behavior was studied at a total pressure of 21.5bar using a H2/CO volume ratio (v/v) of 4 over the temperature range of 160–230°C. Although the H2/CO ratio was greater than typical for FTS due to mass flow controller issues, it was used consistently and the patterns in catalytic behavior observed are representative. A total flow (He, H2 and CO/Ar) of ∼60cm3 min−1 was used, giving a gas-hourly space velocity (GHSV, based on volume of catalyst) at STP of 10,000h−1. This flow was sufficient to operate the reactor in differential mode (conversion<25%). The carbon monoxide cylinder contained 11.8% (v/v) argon as an internal standard to facilitate easy determination of CO conversion. The feed mixture included ∼50% helium (v/v) to minimize temperature gradients inside of the reactor. Two high pressure condensation traps were placed in series after the reactor exit to ensure the complete trapping of the liquid products. Heavier waxy products were collected as liquids in a hot trap at ∼120°C, while lighter liquid products, including water, were collected in a cold trap at 0°C. Non-condensed gases were expanded to 1.034bar and analyzed using an Agilent 6890N gas chromatograph with a 60/80 Carboxen-1000 stainless steel column (Supelco) and a TCD. Reported catalytic performance parameters were obtained after the catalyst had been stabilized—typically after 50h of operation at each temperature, based on the criterion that the standard deviation of the CO and H2 GC areas had stabilized to less than 10% of their average area for at least 6h. Data were collected starting at low temperature, which was increased stepwise until the conversion (X CO) was above 25% for both reactors. Measurements were repeated at some temperatures to confirm sustained catalyst activity. In some cases data above 25% were collected for the more active of the two catalysts tested while waiting for the less active catalyst in the other reactor to reach 25% conversion. Data obtained below 25% conversion (differential reactor) were used to calculate CO depletion rates from Eq. (6). CO conversion (X CO), H2 conversion ( X H 2 ), CH4 selectivity ( S CH 4 ), and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated using Eqs. It can be seen that the deposition order did not significantly affect any of these properties. While there were slight differences, these differences are within the 95% confidence interval. These results are consistent with previous work done by Jacobs et al. [16]. 3.2 Cobalt particle size TEM images were collected for the catalysts after calcination and after reduction/passivation. ACDs calculated from the images taken after calcination are given in Table 2 . As can be seen, co-dep resulted in larger oxide crystallites (after calcination) for the Pt and Re promoted catalysts than for the corresponding seq-dep catalysts. Larger oxide crystallites were also observed for both the co-dep and seq-dep Co/Pt and Co/Ru (but not the Co/Re) when compared to the unpromoted catalyst. ACDs and CSDs determined from TEM images taken after reduction (16h in H2 at 360°C) and passivation are given in Table 2 and Fig. 3 , respectively. When comparing the co-dep catalysts to the seq-dep catalysts for all three NMs, the former were found to have the smallest ACDs. This shift to smaller crystallites was most pronounced for Pt and Ru, and resulted in nearly all particles being below 6nm for all three co-dep catalysts, as shown by the data in the CSD histograms (Fig. 3). 3.3 Metal loading and retention Co and NM loadings were measured for duplicate samples of each calcined catalyst by ICP. The average weight fractions for each catalyst are shown in Table 3 for Co and Table 4 for NM. Co loadings do not show a deposition order trend and are all statistically the same as the target loading of 22.9wt%. Pt and Re loadings are also within experimental error of the intended values for both deposition orders. Ru, however, did show a significant deposition order trend with a very substantial Ru loss of 85% for co-dep compared to a still significant yet lower loss of 54% for seq-dep. In other words, the retention of Ru for seq-dep (46%) was three times the retention of Ru for co-dep (15%). 3.4 Metal distribution The distributions of Co, NM, and La were studied for all catalysts using microprobe analysis. No differences in metal distributions were found for Pt and Re promoted catalysts as a result of deposition order. However, in the case of Ru, Fig. 4 shows some distinct differences between seq-dep and co-dep. For seq-dep, Fig. 4a and b shows a significantly increased concentration of Ru and La on the edge. For the Ru co-dep catalysts, Fig. 4c and d shows a uniform distribution of La and an undetectable Ru distribution. Thus, with Ru promotion, the deposition method does affect the La and potentially the Ru distribution quite significantly. 3.5 Noble metal oxidation state and bonding The NM edge XAFS results after final calcination and after 1h of reduction are given in Table 5 . No notable deposition order effect in either NM oxidation state or atomic-scale bonding was seen. Pt, Ru, and Re promotion resulted in the formation of surface bimetallic PtCo bonds, RuRu metal bonds, and ReO bonds (characteristic of unreduced Re oxide), respectively. An additional Co/Re-co experiment after 400°C reduction rather than 360°C does provide evidence of Re reducibility (from Re2O7 to ReO2), which is consistent with the reducibility trends observed in the next sections. 3.6 TPR profiles TPR (temperature programmed reduction) profiles show the peak temperature and temperature range of the two main reduction steps, i.e. reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co0. Fig. 5 shows the reduction profiles and peak temperatures from the TPR experiments for Re, Pt, and Ru promoted catalysts prepared by both co-dep and seq-dep methods. The temperature of the final reduction peak shows the clearest deposition order effect, i.e. co-dep (especially with Ru and Re as the promoter) shifts this peak to a lower temperature (by 40 and 30°C, respectively, relative to seq-dep). Co/Pt is the least affected by deposition order showing no deposition order effect for the first peak temperature and only a 10°C shift for the second peak, relative to its seq-dep counterpart. 3.7 Extent of reduction, number of active sites, and dispersion Table 6 shows data for EOR, H2 uptake, Co dispersion and approximate average Co crystallite size (calculated from H2 uptake) for the 7 catalysts of this study. It shows that the EORs for the co-dep catalyst are substantially lower than those for the seq-dep catalysts. This is surprising considering the modest differences in the TPR peak 1 temperatures and lower Peak 2 temperatures for the co-dep catalysts. Nevertheless, this may result from the fact that the TPR data are obtained over a relatively short period of time, while EOR data reflect the result of a much longer and more severe reduction (over 16h with 100% H2 flowing). Given the more severe reduction period before EOR measurements and the much smaller ACD for the co-dep catalysts, the lower EOR for the co-dep catalysts likely results from smaller crystallites which are known to be resistant to reduction (see Table 2) [16]. The H2 uptake values (Table 6) for co-dep vs. seq-dep are the same for Co/Pt, slightly lower (10%) for Co/Re and 45% higher for Co/Ru. These values (along with EOR) were used to determine Co dispersions (%D), which range from 10 to 20% for seq-dep but were all ∼19% for the three co-dep catalysts. Thus, Co dispersion for the Co/Ru co-dep preparation is twice that of the corresponding seq-dep catalyst, while for Co/Pt and Co/Re there is little or no difference between co-dep and seq-dep. The H2 uptakes (along with EOR) were also used to estimate average crystallite diameter (d c) for the reduced catalysts. These d c values range from 4.8 to 5.0nm for the co-dep compared to 4.6 to 9.1 for seq-dep. This trend of smaller d c for co-dep is fairly consistent with the ACD data in Table 2 from TEM, which showed values of 4.2 to 4.3nm for the co-dep catalysts compared to 4.9 to 8.0 for the seq-dep. Fig. 6 is a cross plot of d c values vs. ACD values and shows relatively good agreement between the two measurement techniques. 3.8 Activity and selectivity Activity and selectivity data were measured under differential conditions in the fixed bed reactor after quantitative confirmation that the catalysts had reached near steady state, as described earlier. To compare activity and selectivity data at a standard set of conditions, the nearest data point to 200°C (usually within 1–2°C) for each catalyst was normalized to 200°C, P CO of 2.1bar (30psia), and P H 2 of 9.0bar (130psia) using the relationships in Eqs. (11) and (13). The resulting rate data are given in Table 7 . Rate constant (k) values obtained using Eq. (12) for data obtained at CO conversions below 25% were fit to the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (13)) in two different ways (nonlinear and linear regression) to determine activation energies (E A ). The resulting E A values are given in Table 8 . The reaction rates for each of the catalysts are plotted in Fig. 7 as a function of temperature, and nonlinear fits of the data points are represented by the curves. The E A values in Table 8 show that the differences between linear and nonlinear regression are sometimes negligible, as is the case for Co/Ru-seq. Nonetheless, the linear fits weigh the low temperature data more heavily than the nonlinear fits, resulting in a poor fit to the higher temperature data and showing that there can be a significant difference in the values obtained by the two regression methods. This is especially true for Co/Re-seq and Co/Ru-co and is illustrated in Fig. 8 for the former. An examination of the −r CO values (Table 6) shows that deposition order affects rate significantly with all 3 co-dep catalysts being more active than any of the seq-dep catalysts. Specifically, Co/Pt-co>Co/Re-co>Co/Ru-co∼Co≥Co/Pt-seq≥Co/Ru-seq≥Co/Re-seq. This activity trend is also made apparent in Fig. 7, which shows that the unpromoted Co catalyst had approximately the same activity as the Co/Ru-co over the common temperature range studied. The unpromoted Co catalyst was also as active as the Co/Re-co below 170°C; thus, it is only the Pt promoted catalysts that show a deposition order trend such that the co-dep>unpromoted>seq-dep across the entire temperature range. Nevertheless, Re promotion does show this trend for all temperatures above 170°C and all the co-dep catalysts are always more active than the corresponding seq-dep for the entire temperature range. Table 7 also shows TOF data which estimate the activity per site. These data indicate that for Co/Ru the activity per site is approximately the same for both co-dep and seq-dep, but for Co/Pt and Co/Re the activity per site is approximately double for co-dep over seq-dep. Table 7 also specifies the methane selectivity values for each catalyst and indicates that the co-dep selectivities are significantly better (lower) than the seq-dep values for both Pt and Ru promotion, but are the same for Co/Re. 4 Discussion The results of this work provide fresh new insights into the effect of deposition order (including the related effects of thermal treatments) on the properties and performance of Co/NM FT catalysts. In this section the following topics are discussed: (1) Ru retention, (2) Ru and La distribution, (3) Co crystallite size, (4) Co reducibility, and (5) catalyst activity and selectivity. 4.1 Ru retention The results of chemical analysis (ICP) provide evidence of substantial Ru losses during drying and calcination of the Co/Ru catalysts (Table 4) with a greater loss (85%) occurring with co-deposition compared to a lesser, but still significant loss for sequential deposition (52%). This greater loss for co-deposition can be explained by the formation and loss of volatile RuO4 via either (1) reaction of Ru ions with nitric acid solution created by Co nitrate hydrolysis, or (2) by the room temperature reaction of Ru(OH)3. nH2O with Cl2 [26]. Both the nitric acid (from Co nitrate decomposition) and chlorine (from Ru chloride decomposition) routes are likely during co-dep because the calcination of Co nitrate to an oxide occurs in the same step as the Ru deposition. Thus, Ru co-dep results in greater RuO4 formation, which accounts for the greater loss of Ru for this method. On the other hand, the calcination of Co nitrate to an oxide occurs before Ru deposition during seq-dep. As a result of this, only the chlorine route to RuO4 formation is likely for this method. 4.2 Ru and La distribution Electron microprobe data show that Ru and La concentrate at the pellet edge with seq-dep of Ru, but not with co-dep of Ru. This observation suggests the possibility that the Ru and/or La concentration gradients are a result of the final deposition step in seq dep, in which the catalyst precursor contacts only the Ru chloride solution, as opposed to a solution containing both the Co nitrate and Ru chloride as is the case in co-dep. Literature provides possible explanations for the mechanisms of both the Ru and La gradient formation resulting from the catalyst's exposure to aqueous RuCl3. In fact, Ru has been shown to precipitate from RuCl3 solutions when the pH is rapidly increased [27]. Also, Pinna has found that when the RuCl3 solution is poured over the 25wt% Co γ-Al2O3 pellets, its pH is below the point of zero charge for the γ-Al2O3 [28]. As a result of this, the OH groups on the γ-Al2O3 surface gain H+ from the deposition solution, which increases the solution pH and causes the precipitation of Ru from solution. Furthermore, Delmon et al. has shown that this precipitated Ru does not always distribute uniformly across the catalyst [27]. Additionally, it has been shown that strongly adsorbed La will redistribute when exposed to a strong acid [29]. This would account for the La gradient observed in the catalyst prepared via seq-dep, as La was uniformly distributed before it was exposed to the aqueous RuCl3 solution (strong acid) used for the Ru deposition. La redistribution and concentration at the pellet edge (as observed in this study) in the presence of a strong acid (e.g. H2C2O4) has also been observed previously [29]. 4.3 Co crystallite size After calcination, Co oxide crystallite sizes for the Pt and Re-promoted catalysts are larger for co-dep than for seq-dep (see Table 2). This result is counter to that expected based on the number of thermal treatments—since seq-dep catalysts have seen one addition drying/calcination cycle, one might expect them to exhibit more Co agglomeration. It is hypothesized that the pH of the co-dep solution of NM and Co results in the protonation of the Al2O3 hydroxide groups (due to acidity) such that stronger oxide–oxide bonds (stronger Co adsorption) are formed during calcination following the co-deposition step. In fact, deposition solution pH has been shown to affect the protonation of hydroxide groups on the Al2O3 surface, resulting in different Co adsorption strengths [30]. Although, it would seem reasonable to suppose that the Al2O3 surface would be completely covered with Co oxide after calcination of the 20wt% Co precursor (before the Co and NM co-deposition), which would eliminate the likelihood of this protonation effect, the TEM EDS scans of the calcined final catalysts show Co oxide crystallites as well as blank Al2O3. This suggests that there would actually be Al2O3 locations available for the hydroxide group protonation to occur after the calcination of the 20wt% Co deposition. This hypothesis is also consistent with the tailing observed in the CSDs for calcined catalysts shown in Fig. 9 . This phenomenon results from stronger bonds effectively pulling the Co oxide crystallites to the Al2O3, which spreads the Co into thin rafts on the Al2O3 surface. The disappearance of this tailing with reduction (also shown in Fig. 9. by contrasting the gray distribution with the black one) is consistent with the hypothesis that these thin rafts are more likely to break apart and/or ball-up rather than just shrink when the molar volume decreases as O atoms are lost by the reduction to Co metal. This explanation is strengthened by the fact that Co metal has higher surface energy and weaker interactions with the Al2O3 support [31,32]. Thus, it is suggested in future studies that the pH of deposition solution be measured and tracked carefully during preparation. The changes in cobalt crystallite size (ACD) observed going from the calcined form of the catalysts to the reduced form shows some significant differences between the co-dep and seq-dep catalysts. This is particularly significant for Co/Re, as the seq-dep catalyst actually showed increased ACD during reduction. Fig. 10 shows the ratio of the actual change in volume mean ACD going from calcined to reduced state (ΔACDactual) divided by the decrease expected from mere oxygen loss during the reduction from Co3O4 to Co0 (ΔACDexpected). When the ratio is greater than 1, it suggests the number of reduced crystallites that each calcined crystallite divided into. Negative ratios indicate that the reduced crystallites are larger than the calcined, suggesting Co agglomeration. This appears to be the case for Co/Re-seq. The main deposition order effect is that co-dep results in a greater crystallite size decrease with reduction than seq-dep. This is consistent with the idea that deposition order (potentially due to the pH of NM deposition step) influences strength of Co (metal and oxide) interaction with Al2O3. The decrease in size for the co-dep catalysts is 2–4 times greater than the expected particle size decrease based merely on the loss of oxygen. On the other hand, the ACDs for the seq-dep catalysts showed either the expected decrease (Co/Pt-seq), twice the decrease (Co/Ru-seq), or an increase (Co/Re-seq). An unexpected result is that all three reduced co-dep catalysts have nearly the same ACD (4.2±0.1nm) despite the significantly different Co oxide ACDs after calcination (6.1 to 13.6nm). Additionally, the CSDs of the co-dep catalysts after reduction (Fig. 9) are very similar to one another. This sameness and repeatability of co-dep crystallite size suggests the possibility of conducting additional studies in order to optimize crystallite size and further analyze the relationship between the calcined and reduced states. 4.4 Reducibility Greater ease of Co oxide reduction to Co0 for co-dep vs. seq-dep catalysts was manifest by the 10–40°C shifts observed in the second TPR peaks, especially for Co/Ru and Co/Re. These results are consistent with the research of Iglesia, which states that simultaneous calcination of NM and Co precursors promotes reduction by increasing intimate contact between the NM and Co in the final catalyst [19]. The TPR peaks of the Pt promoted catalysts show only slight differences between co-dep and seq-dep, suggesting that Pt's ability to further promote Co reduction when co-deposited is minimal. This is likely tied to the formation of direct PtCo bonds even with seq-dep as was reported in our earlier paper [22] and seen in Table 5. Additionally, the co-dep Re catalyst confirms a previously published result that facilitation of Co reduction does not require all the NM to be reduced to the metal [22]. This is evidenced here by the better reducibility of Co for Co/Re compared to unpromoted Co even though Re remained as Re2O7. This is true for both the co-dep Co/Re (not previously published) as well as for the seq-dep. In summary, the TPR profiles illustrate that co-dep catalysts are more reducible than seq-dep, but the significance of the deposition order effect on TPR behavior is dependent upon NM type. On the other hand, the deposition order effect on reducibility in terms of EOR measurements appears to be reversed from that of the TPR—the co-dep catalysts have lower EORs by 10–15% than the corresponding seq-dep catalysts (Table 6). The lower EORs are likely a result of forming smaller CoO crystallites during the Co3O4 →CoO step. Literature reports have shown that more highly dispersed (smaller) crystallites interact more strongly with the support and have lower EORs [33]. Fig. 11 is consistent with this claim, which plots EOR versus the surface ACD for the reduced form of the 6 catalysts from this study, showing a trend of decreasing EOR with decreasing ACD. 4.5 Activity The data given in Table 7 and Fig. 7 show that all co-dep catalysts, despite having lower EORs are more active per gram than the coresponding seq-dep catalysts by 35–135%. Fig. 12 , which is a graphical illustration of similar data as that found in Table 7, except they are corrected to a H2/CO ratio of 2, also shows this trend very well. For the Co/Pt and Co/Re, the deposition order difference in activity is statistically significant—the 90% confidence intervals do not overlap as seen in Fig. 13a and b. On the other hand, the difference for the Co/Ru catalysts is not statistically significant (Fig. 13c). In the case of Co/Pt, the co-dep catalysts is also statistically more active than the unpromoted catalyst (Fig. 13a). It is possible that the extreme loss of Ru is what hindered the same trend from being apparent in Co/Ru. A Gulf patent showing an increased activity with low Ru loading (0.1wt%) [17] suggests, however, that the ability of Ru to promote FT activity could have occurred even at the low final Ru loading of this study. Therefore, the decrease in activity is believed to be due to not only the poor Ru retention, but also the uneven metal distribution. Also, it is observed that all 3 of the seq-dep catalysts have lower activity than the unpromoted catalyst while all 3 of the co-dep catalysts have the same or higher activity—Co/Pt-co and Co/Re-co are 50–70% higher while Co/Ru is essentially the same. Thus, it appears that the extra impregnation step to add NM by seq-dep was not only ineffective, but actually deterimental in terms of both activity and selectivity. The observation of higher activity (rate per gram) for the co-dep catalysts begs the question of whether they simply have more sites, or if their activity per site is higher. This question can be answered by comparing the data in Tables 6 and 7. For Co/Pt and Co/Re the number of sites from H2 uptake are approximately the same for either deposition method (within 15%), but the activity per site is approximately 2 and 3 times greater, respectively. Thus, clearly co-dep of Pt and Re gives a signifcant advantage over seq-dep. For Co/Ru, the number of sites is 45% greater for co-dep, but the rate per gram is only 35% greater, and therefore the activity per site is actually lower for the co-dep. Thus, there is a clear distinction here. The slight increase in activity for Co/Ru is due to a higher abundance of active sites, and not due to an increase in activity per site, while for Co/Pt and Co/Re there is a clear increase in activity per site. The higher TOF for Co/Pt-co is somewhat surprising because its ACD is only 4.3nm (with 91% of crystallites<6nm), compared to 8.0nm (with 26% of crystallites<6nm) for Co/Pt-seq. This result is surprising because literature shows that unpromoted catalysts with crystallites below 6nm generally have lower TOFs [21,34,35] than those with larger crystallites in the 6 to 12nm range. Thus, our results could suggest that the previous work for unpromoted Co catalysts may not extend to promoted Co catalysts. den Breejen et al. gives an explanation for the decrease in TOF with decreasing particle size in unpromoted catalysts—the edge and corner sites are blocked with irreversibly adsorbed CO [36]. It is possible that this effect is overcome by NM addition and/or that the crystallite size trend is not applicable here. The ‘protective effect’ of inhibiting carbon deposition during FT reactions seen by Iglesia [37] suggests that NMs could hinder blockage of the edge and corner sites. In addition, it is also possible that La is influencing CO dissociation and thus allowing for increased TOF, as La has been shown to enhance CO dissociation in NM systems [38]. Thus, the results of this study indicate that either the 6–12nm “ideal” range for Co crystallites is not applicable – in agreement with the work of Johnson et al., which showed that CO hydrogenation is crystallite size insensitive [39,40] – or the general effects of particle size are in some way overcome by promotion (NM and La) and/or NM deposition order. There is also another possible explanation for this particle size observation. It could be that the negative effects of the seq-dep method of adding NM with its additional calcination step outweigh the positive effects of the larger crystallites, and that if it were possible to produce co-dep catalysts with 8nm crystallites instead of 4nm that they would be even more active. It is clear that there is still work that needs to be done to resolve this issue. The lower methane selectivity for co-dep Co/Pt and Co/Ru catalysts are also interesting trends in that they run counter to the generally accepted crystallite size trend of smaller crystallites having higher methane selectivities. Thus, smaller Co crystallites in intimate contact with NM promoters give catalysts with higher activity and better (lower methane) selectivity. 5 Conclusions The major conclusion from this study is that the co-dep method to add noble metal promoters to Co FTS catalysts is significantly better than the seq-dep method; it produces catalysts that have higher activity and lower methane selectivity and requires less work in their preparation. The present work makes a comprehensive comparison of several properties for Co catalysts – namely, (i) metal retention, (ii) metal spatial distribution, (iii) Co crystallite size, (iv) Co reducibility, and (v) FT activity and selectivity – and leads to the following property specific conclusions. (1) Ru retention is poor and shows a deposition order trend with seq-dep resulting in higher retention than co-dep (48% vs 15%). Pt and Re show excellent retention for both methods with no deposition order trend. (2) Metal distribution is affected by deposition order for Co/Ru catalysts: Co/Ru-co shows uniform Ru and La distributions, whereas the Co/Ru-seq catalysts do not. Pt and Re promoted catalysts show a uniform distribution regardless of the deposition order used. (3) The co-deposition method produces catalysts with smaller Co crystallites after reduction than the seq-dep. All three co-deposited catalysts had a surface-averaged ACD (TEM) of 4.2nm compared to values of 5–8nm for their seq-dep counterparts. The change in ACD in going from the calcined to the reduced form of the catalysts was much greater for the co-dep than the seq-dep catalysts. (4) The predominant NM bonding following mild reduction (4% H2, 1h, 360°C) does not show a deposition order effect as measured by XAFS. Pt, Ru, and Re promotion by both deposition orders results in the formation of surface bimetallic PtCo bonds, RuRu metal bonds, and ReO bonds (characteristic of unreduced Re oxide), respectively. (5) The temperature required for reduction of the calcined catalysts to Co metal is lower (by 10–40°C) for co-dep catalysts relative to the seq-dep ones for all NMs. This is seen by downward shifts in the temperatures of the second peak in the TPR profiles. (6) Extents of reduction for catalysts prepared by co-dep (range from 77–91%, average 84%) are lower by 15% (on average) than those prepared by seq-dep (62–77%, average 71%). (7) The CO depletion rates for the Pt and Re co-dep catalysts are statistically higher than their corresponding seq-dep catalysts (by 100 and 135%, respectively). The relative activities for Ru promoted catalysts (co-dep vs seq-dep) are not statistically different. (8) TOFs for the co-dep catalysts are higher than for the seq-dep catalysts (by 70–80% for Pt and Re promoted catalysts) thus indicating that co-dep gives higher site-specific activity. (9) In this study larger Co crystallites made by seq-dep (e.g. Co/Pt-seq had ACD of 8.0nm and 26%<6nm) were less active than smaller Co crystallites made by co-dep (e.g. Co/Pt-co had ACD of 4.3nm with 91%<6nm) which appears counter to previous studies on unpromoted Co which indicate 6–12nm crystallites give the optimum activity. (10) Methane selectivities of Co/Pt and Co/Ru prepared by co-dep are lower than for seq-dep by 36% and 18%, respectively. Thus, from conclusion 5 and this one, lower methane selectivity is correlated with higher extent of reduction, consistent with the early work of Reuel and Bartholomew [33]. (11) The co-dep Co/Pt catalyst is statistically more active than the unpromoted Co catalyst while its corresponding seq-dep counterpart is less active. coredata.dc:description: The effect of noble metal (NM) promoter (Pt, Re, or Ru) deposition order was investigated for commercially-representative Co Fischer–Tropsch catalysts (nominally 25wt% Co on a La stabilized alumina support). The effects of deposition sequence (co-deposition vs. sequential deposition) were studied in terms of NM retention and distribution, Co crystallite size, Co reducibility, and catalyst activity and selectivity. Ru retention was <48% for both sequences with the most severe losses for co-deposition (85% loss). Sequentially deposited Co/Ru showed poor Ru distribution, unlike co-deposited Co/Ru. Excellent retention and uniform distribution were observed for both Pt and Re promoted catalysts. Cobalt crystallite sizes were smaller for all three co-deposited catalysts (∼4.2nm for all NMs) when compared to any of the sequentially deposited catalysts. Although sequentially deposited catalysts required higher reduction temperatures (TPR), they had greater extents of reduction (EORs) relative to co-deposited catalysts. CO depletion rates and turnover frequencies (TOFs) for co-deposited Co/Pt and Co/Re were 2–3 times higher than their sequentially deposited counterparts. Methane selectivities were lower for the same two co-deposited catalysts. It is noteworthy that the smaller Co crystallites, produced by co-deposition, resulted in more active catalysts than those with larger crystallites resulting from sequential deposition. The co-deposited Co/Pt catalyst was found to be statistically more active than the unpromoted Co catalyst, while the corresponding sequentially deposited catalyst was less active. Overall, co-deposited Co/Pt and Co/Re catalysts showed superior catalytic performance by all standards of judgment when compared to their sequentially deposited counterparts.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of promoter deposition order on platinum-, ruthenium-, or rhenium-promoted cobalt Fischer–Tropsch catalysts
